-e ---
---
All languages have ways to express causation but differ in the means. Most, if not all, languages have lexical causative forms.  
English:  
 rise â†’ raise, lie â†’ lay, sit â†’ set (make something sit)  
 saint â‡¨ sanctify (faire=do)  
 glad  â‡¨ gladden (dan,done,do)  

Related to perfective completive

In Akkadian the Å -stem is formed by adding a prefix Å¡-, and these forms are mostly causatives.  
Causative or intensive forms are also formed with the doubled D-stem. áƒ’áƒ [DO](DO.html) (Tat)
